Great job comparing and contrasting resistance, capacitive reactance, inductive reactance  and impedence. I wish though he explained why the resonance frequency is important. At resonance, XL equals XC, meaning they cancel each other out. This leaves the impedance of the circuit to be purely resistive. As a result, the current that flows through the series RLC circuit is at its peak when it’s operating at its resonant frequency.

It helps to think of impedance as a local quantity that relates to 2 sinusoidal quantities in the complex plane  represented as phasors. Those 2 sinusoidal quantities being voltage drop across and current thru a capacitor or inductor or resistor. Because impedance is an ohm's law based quantity it's expression for inductor has j in it (voltage leads current) and has -j in expression for capacitor (voltage lags current).
